Raymond Roth, 48, of Massapequa, New York, was first e6:reported e7:missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year-old son, Jonathan Roth. Several days into an extensive e8:search involving multiple agencies, New York State Park Police e9:said, authorities e10:learned the missing man was in South Carolina, where he had been e11:pulled over for e1000:speeding.

The day before Raymond Roth was e12:pulled over, his wife, Evana, e13:showed authorities e-mails she had e14:discovered that e15:appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to e2001:fake his e16:death. Raymond Roth e17:wanted his wife and son to e18:collect at least $410,000 in life insurance benefits while he e19:started a new life in Florida, Rice e20:said.

State police e21:arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud, conspiracy and filing a false report. Raymond Roth on Thursday e23:agreed to e24:plead guilty to the conspiracy e25:charge in exchange for a e26:sentence of 90 days in jail and five years' probation, the district attorney's office e27:said. He also must e28:pay restitution for the cost of the e29:search -- $27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department.

Evana Roth e30:told CNN in August she e31:thought her husband e32:devised the plan after he was e33:fired from his job in July. Her attorney, Lenard Leeds, e34:said she had been e2003:unaware of the e35:ruse before she e36:uncovered the e-mail e1001:correspondence.

Microsoft Corp. e1:broke sales records in 2010 when it e2:released its Kinect - a movement-tracking device that e3:enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone, without need of a controller.

Now, with the e6:help of outside developers, the software giant is e7:hoping to e8:move the Kinect beyond gaming.

Microsoft is e9:expanding into China with a company-funded incubator program for outside developers to e1000:build products based on Kinect technology for a range of industries including health care and retail.

In the U.S., 11 companies were e10:selected last year for the accelerator's first three-month class in Seattle, out of nearly 500 applicants. Microsoft e11:said it has e12:identified three companies for the China program to e13:run through June.

The company e14:gives each participating startup in the Seattle program $20,000 to e15:create software that can be used with Kinect for Windows, but it is isn't e17:asking for any ownership stakes or intellectual property rights. Microsoft also doesn't e18:have any veto power over the ideas.

What Microsoft e19:gets are developers around the world e20:working on ideas that could potentially e21:open up Kinect for Windows' technology to new markets - and e22:convince consumers and businesses to e23:buy the company's hardware and make e25:use of the potential apps.

The Windows-ready Kinect sensor, which would be necessary for any business that e26:wants to e27:use these potential new technologies, is currently selling for e28:$250 through Microsoft, more than twice what Microsoft charges for the gaming-only Xbox version.

The flu e1000028:season is winding down, and it has e2:killed 105 children so far - about the average toll.

The season e3:started about a month earlier than usual, e4:sparking concerns it might e5:turn into the worst in a decade. It e6:ended up being very hard on the elderly, but was moderately severe overall, e7:according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Six of the pediatric e1000030:deaths were e8:reported in the last week, and it's possible there will be more, e9:said the CDC's Dr. Michael Jhung e10:said Friday.

Roughly 100 children e11:die in an average flu season. One exception was the swine flu e1000032:pandemic of 2009-2010, when 348 children e12:died.

The CDC e13:recommends that all children ages 6 months and older be e2001:vaccinated against flu each season, though only about half get a flu shot or nasal spray.

All but four of the children who e16:died were old enough to be e17:vaccinated, but 90 percent of them did not get e19:vaccinated, CDC officials e20:said.

This year's vaccine was e21:considered effective in children, though it didn't e22:work very well in older people. And the dominant flu strain early in the e2002:season was one that tends to cause more severe illness.

The government only does a national flu death count for children. But it does track hospitalization rates for people 65 and older, and those statistics have been e1000033:grim.

In that group, 177 out of every 100,000 were e26:hospitalized with flu-related illness in the past several months. That's more than 2 1/2 times higher than any other recent season.

This flu e2003:season e27:started in early December, a month earlier than usual, and e1000035:peaked by the end of year. Since then, flu reports have been e28:dropping off throughout the country.

"We e29:appear to be e30:getting close to the end of flu e2004:season," Jhung e31:said.

Six of the pediatric e1000030:deaths were e8:reported in the last week, and it's possible there will be more, e9:said the CDC's Dr. Michael Jhung e10:said Friday.

The CDC e13:recommends that all children ages 6 months and older be e2001:vaccinated against flu each season, though only about half get a flu shot or nasal spray.

All but four of the children who e16:died were old enough to be e17:vaccinated, but 90 percent of them did not get e19:vaccinated, CDC officials e20:said.

This year's vaccine was e21:considered effective in children, though it didn't e22:work very well in older people. And the dominant flu strain early in the e2002:season was one that tends to cause more severe illness.

The government only does a national flu death count for children. But it does track hospitalization rates for people 65 and older, and those statistics have been e1000033:grim.

In that group, 177 out of every 100,000 were e26:hospitalized with flu-related illness in the past several months. That's more than 2 1/2 times higher than any other recent season.

China's state leadership e43:transition has e1:taken place this month against an ominous backdrop. More than 16,000 dead pigs have been e2:found e3:floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai. A haze akin to volcanic fumes e4:cloaked the capital, e5:causing convulsive e6:coughing and e7:obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City.

So severe are China's environmental woes, especially the noxious air, that top government officials have been e8:forced to openly e9:acknowledge them. Fu Ying, the spokeswoman for the National People's Congress, e10:said she e11:checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and e13:kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself. Li Keqiang, the new prime minister, e14:said the air pollution had e15:made him "quite e44:upset" and e16:vowed to "e17:show even greater resolve and make more vigorous e19:efforts" to e20:clean it up.

Last month, after deadly air pollution e21:hit record levels in northern China, officials e22:led byWen Jiabao, then the prime minister, e23:put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years. But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will e24:comply, especially since oil officials e25:resisted a similar government order for higher-grade fuel four years ago. State-owned power companies have been similarly e46:resistant. The companies regularly ignore government orders to e26:upgrade coal-burning electricity plants, e27:according to ministry data. And as with the oil companies, the power companies e28:exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates.

The report e41:estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit e42:400 million by 2030, up from e1000:90 million now.
